diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: Characteristics align with SLE which frequently presents with malar (or butterfly) rash, fever, and can also affect the brain causing delirium. Lupus can lead to inflammation of various body systems including the heart, presenting as acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by an autoimmune reaction to a streptococcal infection. It can present with fever and rash, along with cardiac involvement, which may manifest as acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Infective endocarditis can cause fever, Osler’s nodes (which can be mistaken as rashes), and acute pericarditis due to the infection spreading or forming immune complexes.

diagnoses.name: Still's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A rare type of inflammatory arthritis that features fevers, rash, and can affect the organs, including the heart lining.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pericarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Common viruses can cause pericarditis, presenting with fever and potentially rashes depending on the causative virus, often accompanied by chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi transmitted via ticks. It presents with fever, erythema migrans which is a type of annular rash, and can lead to cardiac involvement including pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory condition characterized by muscle weakness and skin rashes, which can sometimes mimic annular rashes. It's associated with systemic symptoms like fever and can have cardiac involvement.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus
diagnoses.rationale: Certain medications can induce a lupus-like syndrome presenting with symptoms like rash, fever, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs including the skin, presenting as various types of rashes, fever, and it can have cardiac implications like pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: A disease that presents with features of several connective tissue diseases including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis. Symptoms include fever, rashes, and it can affect the heart.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Lupus Erythematosus with Nervous System Involvement
Malignancies such as Leukemia or Lymphoma
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, if not due to organic cause)
Secondary Immunodeficiency Disease due to External Factors

diagnoses.name: Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders that affect the body's ability to fight infections and diseases, leading to increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A long-standing condition where the blood pressure in the arteries is persistently elevated, which can affect organ systems and lead to various complications.

diagnoses.name: Vascular Malformations
diagnoses.description: Refers to blood vessels that have not formed properly, including angiomata, which can sometimes be associated with systemic syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A painful disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that normally lines the inside of your uterus — the endometrium — grows outside your uterus.

diagnoses.name: Lymphadenopathy or Lymphadenitis
diagnoses.description: Conditions involving the inflammation or enlargement of the lymph nodes, often due to infection, cancer, or other diseases.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.description: A broad category of conditions wherein the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy cells, potentially explaining a combination of symptoms including increased infection risk and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Diseases
diagnoses.description: Diseases characterized by long-term inflammation that can affect various parts of the body, potentially explaining the presence of endometriosis and angiomata.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatous Diseases
diagnoses.description: Diseases characterized by the formation of granulomas, which are small areas of inflammation, can cause lymphadenitis and increase susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation (angiomata) and can cause a variety of symptoms depending on the location and severity of the blood vessel abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Hypertension due to Endocrine Disorders
diagnoses.description: Hypertension resulting from an underlying endocrine disorder, such as thyroid disease, adrenal gland tumors, or conditions that affect hormone levels which could indirectly influence susceptibility to infections and the development of lymphadenitis.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's granulomatosis)
Sleep Disorder Related to Another Mental Condition

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the liver, which can be caused by viruses, medications, or alcohol. It can present with abnormal liver enzymes, oral pain, and go along with increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth. It can lead to oral pain and abnormal liver enzymes.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome can cause abnormal liver enzymes, increased susceptibility to infections, lymphadenitis, and indirectly lead to conditions causing oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, leading to a wide array of symptoms including abnormal liver enzymes, increased susceptibility to infections, and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often known as mono, this viral infection can cause liver enzyme abnormalities, lymphadenitis, and increased susceptibility to infection. Oral pain can occur due to enlarged tonsils or mouth ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, commonly the lungs and lymph glands. It can cause abnormal liver enzymes, lymphadenitis, and might relate to hypothermia due to systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system, leading to lymphadenitis. It can also affect the liver enzyme levels and compromise the immune system, increasing the risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Alcoholic Liver Disease
diagnoses.description: Damage to the liver and its function due to excessive alcohol intake. Can cause abnormal liver enzymes and increase susceptibility to infections due to compromised liver functions.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hepatitis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks liver cells, leading to abnormal liver enzymes, potential hypothermia due to liver function impairment, and increased infection risk.

diagnoses.name: Graft vs Host Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs after an allogeneic tissue transplant where the donor's immune cells attack the recipient's tissues. It can cause abnormal liver enzymes, lymphadenitis, oral pain, and increased infection risk.

diagnoses: Potassium Disorders (e.g., Hypokalemia or Hyperkalemia depending on the nature of episodic weakness)
Secondary Hypertension (due to the combination of symptoms that might suggest an underlying condition causing hypertension)
Thyroiditis (as hypothyroidism might be a symptom)
Autoimmune Thyroid Disease (such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, which can lead to hypothyroidism)
Anemia (especially if hemorrhoids lead to significant blood loss, might also contribute to weakness)
Adrenal Insufficiency (Adrenal glands not producing enough of certain hormones could lead to symptoms like weakness and hypertension)
Chronic Venous Insufficiency (could be related to hemorrhoids and peripheral symptoms)
Hereditary Angioedema (rare, but could theoretically cause episodic weakness and has been associated with dermatographism in some cases)
Secondary Thrombocytosis due to Infection or Inflammation
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis)
Foreign body in the respiratory system

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal syncope
diagnoses.description: A common cause of fainting, occurring in response to a trigger like severe emotional distress, leading to temporary loss of consciousness.

diagnoses.name: Orthostatic hypotension
diagnoses.description: A form of low blood pressure that happens when standing up from sitting or lying down, which may cause fainting or dizziness.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when you use or lose more fluid than you take in, causing weakness, dizziness, and sometimes hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can cause shock, a sudden drop in blood pressure, and collapse.

diagnoses.name: Septic shock
diagnoses.description: A severe infection leading to dangerously low blood pressure and organ dysfunction, often with rapid onset of severe symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Addison's disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which the adrenal glands don’t produce enough hormones, leading to fatigue, muscle weakness, hypotension, and sometimes abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Toxic shock syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections, often associated with tampon use, causing sudden high fever, rash, low blood pressure, and malaise.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection marked by diarrhea, cramps, nausea, vomiting, and sometimes muscle aches or fever.

diagnoses.name: Acute pancreatitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pancreas that occurs suddenly and causes severe upper abdominal pain, potentially radiating to the back and accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and possibly hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Adrenal crisis
diagnoses.description: A life-threatening condition that occurs when there's a severe shortage of cortisol, leading to nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, profound weakness, hypotension, and potentially shock.

diagnoses: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) exacerbation with allergic component
Multiple Sclerosis (considering incontinence and neurological symptoms)
Diabetes Mellitus (particularly for its potential to cause incontinence and pruritus)

diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing weakness, coordination, balance difficulties, and other problems.
A type of headache that is often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. Aura symptoms may include visual disturbances and other sensory changes.
A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves, leading to muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis.
Occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.
A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body.
A neurological disease that mainly involves the nerve cells (neurons) responsible for controlling voluntary muscle movement. The disease is progressive, meaning the symptoms get worse over time.
Inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause a sudden loss of vision usually in one eye, pain with eye movement, and sometimes photophobia.
Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. It usually lasts less than 24 hours and often does not cause permanent damage.
A rare neurological disorder that affects your body's involuntary functions, including blood pressure, heart rate, bladder function, and digestion.
Can be either benign or malignant. Symptoms can vary greatly depending on the brain tumor's location and size. Common symptoms include headaches, seizures, nausea, weakness, and sensory changes.

diagnoses: Neurodegenerative Disorders (e.g., Parkinson's Disease, Huntington's Disease)
Hepatitis B or C associated Polyarteritis Nodosa
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
HELLP Syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets)
Evans syndrome (Autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Vasculitis, such as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
Evans syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
